person.note: H. Lewis Ulman is Associate Professor of English at The Ohio State University and Director of Digital Media Studies in the Department of English. He has edited The Minutes of the Aberdeen Philosophical Society, 1758–1773 (Aberdeen University Press, 1990) and, with Dennis Quon, “Semiotics in Eighteenth-century Aberdeen: Thomas Gordon’s Contributions to the Aberdeen Philosophical Society” (Studies on Voltaire and the Eighteenth-Century 317 (1994): 57–115). He is also the author of Things, Thoughts, Words and Actions: The Problem of Language in Late Eighteenth-Century British Rhetorical Theory (Southern Illinois University Press, 1994). Since 2005, he has worked with undergraduate and graduate students in textual editing courses to create a series of electronic textual editions of nineteenth- and early twentieth-century American manuscripts in the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at Ohio State. An example of that work can be viewed online at http://people.cohums.ohio-state.edu/ulman1/SSCoxJournal/. Beginning with an NEH Digital Humanities Start-Up Grant awarded in 2008, he has collaborated with Melanie Schlosser, metadata librarian at Ohio State University Libraries, to build a model of preservation for distributed, multimodal digital humanities projects. He is delighted to be working at a time when manuscript, print, and digital media can be studied in relationship to one another, allowing him and his students to learn more about all three media than they could by studying any one in isolation.

projectDesc.p: This edition is the latest in a series of collaboratively produced electronic editions of previously unpublished nineteenth-century American manuscripts held in the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University. Previous editions include "My Dear Elizabeth," five letters written by Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to her sister Elizabeth Palmer Peabody between ca. 1837 and 1868 (currently being revised); "Dear Wife," twenty-one letters written by riverboat captain William B. Anderson to his wife Louisa while he plied the Ohio river during the height of the American Civil War, 1862–1864; "Journal of a Tour to Europe," by Samuel Sullivan Cox; and "Louisa A. Doane's Journal of Two Ocean Voyages (1852-1853). These documentary editions are intended to provide wide exposure and access to manuscripts that might otherwise be difficult for scholars to discover and consult, and to provide users with a variety of tools for studying those texts.

Each text was edited in connection with an undergraduate or graduate course offered by H. Lewis Ulman, Associate Professor of English at The Ohio State University. The courses provide students with an opportunity to explore issues of textuality and mediation that arise when our cultural archives spread from page to screen and from library shelves to networked databases. Electronic textual editing serves as our vehicle for examining what happens—and envisioning what might happen—when artifacts in one medium are represented in another medium, especially with regard to the interpretive work of reading. Electronic textual editions also provide a contact zone that can help us reflect on what manuscript, print, and "born digital" artifacts can tell us about their unique properties and their relationships to one another.

While providing a reliable textual edition is a sine qua non, the Lockhart edition also explores ways of telling four stories inextricably woven into our work: the lives and historical milieu evoked by the texts, the history of the physical journal, the editorial process that gave rise to this particular interpretation of the text, and the mediation of our electronic delivery system.

editorialDecl.p: Scanning. The manuscript pages were scanned as 24-bit TIFF images at 400 dots per inch (dpi), then coverted to 8-bit JPEG images at 400 dpi and full quality before being loaded into the Media Manager application. All edges were overscanned by at least 1/4 inch. No color correction was used at any stage of image preparation, but a scan of a photographer's 18% grey card on the same scanner produced RGB values at the center of 91/95/107 after applying a 150% Gaussian Blur in Adobe Photoshop to average color values. Thus, a properly configured monitor should provide a reasonable approximation of colors on the manuscript pages.

Production Location of Digital Assets. The TEI P5-encoded transcription of the Smith journal, along with XSL style sheets used to provide variant "views" of the edition, TEI ODD documents used to produce custom schemas based on the TEI markup language, and the resulting schemas are stored on a server hosted by College of Arts and Sciences at The Ohio State University and on a Google SVN repository. Readers may download copies of those source files via a link at the top of this page. High resolution scans of the manuscript pages, scans of plates from contemporary sources, and photographs of the journal are stored in the Media Manager application hosted by the College of Arts and Science at The Ohio State University. The files constituting the project's Web site are stored on a Web server hosted by the College (http://people.cohums.ohio-state.edu/ulman1/LCSmithDiaries/).
Archiving of Digital Assets. Once the edition is complete, its digital assets will be archived in The Ohio State University Knowledge Bank (https://kb.osu.edu/dspace/).

refsDecl.p: Markup of Physical Structure and Page Layout. The manuscript pages, encoded by the empty page break or <pb/> element, are the primary physical structures represented in the markup. Each <pb> element includes a "facs" attribute identifying the unique ID of a high-resolution scan of that image in the Media Manager application. Line breaks (i.e., lineation determined or influenced by the physical constraints of the page rather than compositional choices by the author) are encoded with the empty <lb/> element. No attributes are included in the <lb> element. Because Smith wrote on lined paper, when he skips a line printed on the paper for any reason, we encode a <lb/> that, in the view arranged by manuscript pages and lines, will appear as an empty numbered line.

Markup of Textual Structure. The diary entry, encoded by a <div> element with the attribute-value pair "type='Entry'", constitutes the primary textual structure represented in the markup. Each entry contains a <dateline> element and one or more paragraphs. Each dateline may include a <name> element with (optionally) a @type attribute containing one of the following values: city, region; and a <date> element with a @when attribute whose value is in the form YYYY-MM-DD. The value of the @when attribute represents the editors' judgment about the actual date when the entry was composed; the contents of the <date> element represent what Smith actually wrote, even if he entered the date incorrectly.

Entries consist of a series of paragraphs. Where indicated by context, indentation of a line from the left margin of a page, line breaks part-way across a page, or additional white space between lines, paragraphs are encoded with the

element and no attributes.
If present, any prefatory text preceding the dateline may be encoded as a <head> element at the beginning of an entry (i.e., within the <div>element and before the <dateline>).

Level of Transcription/Encoding. This markup scheme supports a modest range of presentations, from semi-modernized/corrected to semi-diplomatic. The basic transcription follows the manuscript verbatim. Various manuscript features (e.g., cancellations, interlinear or marginal additions, tears in pages) are encoded, as are regularized versions of proper names and dates and standard versions of nonstandard spellings and expansions of abbreviations.

Customization of the TEI P5 Schema. Customization consisted primarily of restricting encoding to certain modules and elements as well as enforcing some attribute values. See the ODD file for complete details.

Journal covering period Dec 25 1940 until return home
about May 1st 1941

div.p:
At the exact moment when christmas bells should have
begun ringing here in the Antarctic if any christmas bells
had been available, Pack Jack Tony and I were making
our last big "Putsch" toward the base We had left
Fort Wiener at 930 PM and at 11 PM when we were
only 10.5 miles from the base decided not to camp until
morning but push on in. Tony and the rest While we were
resting we drank a toast to ourselves — as a party — and
to a merry christmas, finishing up the half a pint which
I had nursed along so carefully for two and a half months. Tony
and I started out again and again and for a while had some
difficulty staying ahead of the dogs. They were running now
just as well as they did when we first hit the good
surface we were travelling over. Jack and Sevene still
combining new teams and he was driving them. Dinch and
Pearl were pinched up in the loads. I am quite certain
that we should never have made the base when we did.
if we hadn't combinded our teams. As one o'clock we
could just see the base and the airplane looming on the
horizon. Tony had been seeing things for several hours
but always he had to say I guess I was wrong
when a large trail flag br came into view. All sorts
of thoughts began clicking through our minds as the base.

Christmas spirit and strawberry pie to top things off then
more? until show time. We saw the Jones family
Hollywood and Risky Business. I enjoyed both of them.

It had been blowing about 35-40 miles an hour all day
and drifting so badly that I decided to sleep in.Jack
however braved the storm and slept out. All in

All in all this has by far been the most eventful
Christmas I have ever experienced.

I prepared what will probably be my usual piece-de-resistance
scrambled eggs ala Lockhart. These with toast and coffee
completed the morning repast.

In the laboratory I learned up a little more and am now
ready to begin metabolism tests in the morning. Tony will
be the first victim. I also changed water on the socks I
had been soaking overnight and then sat down to read a bit
more in Death Sails with Magellan. Charles Ford the
author certainly had done a marvellous job in this book
I shall have to get it for my own library when I get home.

that he rolls the oranges before squeezing out the the juice in order
to get the citric acid out of the skin. Shirley argues that he
rolls the oragnes in order to break the skin and the cellular
structure inside. They appealed to me being the chemist to
settle the argument. I tried to steer clear but finally sided
with Shirley which action made the cook leak water a
little --- but not much.

I began reading Gone with the Wind and hope it won't
take too much of my time.

I have come back from the trail with an intense desire to
do some more camping - preferably in Canada - and all the
other activities that go with it hunting and fishing. I
presume that the best way to begin is to go some advertised
camp and hire a guide for a week or so. I shall get

I shall get out of this mess line and go to bed where
I can read in peace.

div.p:
We have been operating such an erratic schedule and
also have to deal with Greenwich Mean Time that
I have been confused concerning the day and date for
several days. Yesterday I thought today was to be New Year
and now that we are actually in the New Year by camp
schedule I am still during today. Now, however, I think
I am fairly well straightened out.

Yesterday which normally would have been written up early
this morning slipped by with no entry entirely because I had
gotten so far into Gone with the Wind that wartime was a thing
of minor importance. I read that amazing episnarrative of life
among the Southerners during the Civil War days until almost
AM. I wasn't reading all of the time but enough of the time
so that work which should be the main object these days
stagnated. The book which begins I mildly and almost
boringly soon gets under way and its power makes itself
evident. The South which has been a mystery to me and
no doubt to countless other americans will soon become in
my mind something more than the land of cotton, belles,
"gentlemen" and mint juleps. Perhaps even the answer to
the legendary or hereditary hate most Southerners have
for Northeners in general would be evident. At any rate
I felt then that I should get a little American History into

my head in an entirely pleasant manner. Now after
having continued my reading through that part of the book
in which the war has ended and the "Cause" lost do I do
begin to get the idea underlying all of the hatred that has
been instilled in the present generation by parents, grand
parents or even great grand parents the latter of whom were
the younger generation of those never-to-be-forgotten days.
If the Yankees had been able to win the war without
the Sherman-in-Atlanta episode perhaps all of the
stigma which now is attached thto the word Northener
might have been avoided. Conerning the Civil War no
one can say "that's all ancient History" because in
the South, as far as I can gather from some of the Southern boys
here, the Civil War is still being fought with almost the
same intensity as in the days of the actual war itself. I
am now about to embark on the history of the post war days
which are to be considered as bad if not worse than those
the war days themselves.

Yesterday I worked on Tony again and today should have
worked of on Jack Richardson but he was up even later
than I so I didn't bother to wake him at ten this morning.

Last night part of the time was spent analyzing air
samples that had been taken outside. The interesting part
of this work was the very low percentage of oxygen in the air
the carbon dioxide value which was relatively quite high
was not as accurate a result as the oxygen value so cannot
hold as much importance as the latter. In taking these

samples I am cooperating with Court the meteorologist who
tells me when to take the samples. The prime requisite is
that the wind must have been blowing steadily from one
direction for more than six hours. I shall do as many
of these analyses as time and energy — mostly energy — will
permit. When correlated with the weather data Court has they
should be of some value to whomever studies that sort of
thing. My interest in the matter lies only in the fact that
I may be the only man for some time to come who will have
an accurate apparatus for gas analysis here in the Antarctic.

I tried to get some shots at skua gulls with the hand
gun but evidently they have become somewhat man shy because
I couldn't get close enough to shoot. I shall have to learn
to shoot the shot gun so that I can get them on the wing.

Tonight at radio schedule time we learned that the boys
want to abandon the tractor; they just can't make any progress
at all. The tractor goes into the snow up to its belly even
with no load. In order not to lose the valuable loads which
have been made even heavier by the addition of the outpost's
stuff it has been decided to send Tony and Jack out with
18 dogs and two sleds. Ferranto is hauling several dog sleds
which are extra so that the single do sled dog teams can
once more be brought ba made double sled dog teams. At

I read them all all over again. I had one from May
which had in it some pictures of Carl and her and
one of one of her sisters. I enjoyed also the pictures
Beatie sent of Pete, Peter, Papa, and the house. Both
Van and Vivian sent letters with pictures in them of the
new baby. George also sent pictures in his letter. Other
letters came from Dave and Marry, Henery, Dot, Eleanor
Jeanene. I had one of the most pleasent of times
I have had in a long while.
runs away occasionally.

I made up some Benedict's for Due and he shows
a negative test.

Pete and Wiener made their hop this afternoon. Pete
wants to crack this altitude record he set up last fall. Lumy?
is cromie? my observer and also will take charge of the bottles
I sent up for air samples. When they came down I got
some pictures of the landing. Wiener had carried out my
instructions and I removed the flasks. They went up only to
17000 ft because the rubber tubing caused the wings to
vibrate. After dinner I got Buck to light his dry? flu? torch
so that I could seal off the flasks. It was unsucessful
because the pressure inside the flasks was so great that
holes blew outwere made in in the tubing where it was heated. I have
one flask that will be good enough for air analysis have
but only as an indicator.

I had a "gram" from his men saying she was sorry
not to have sent mail on the Star but would have letters
for me in Valpo.

I didn't do much else but sit around and talk to
Klimdike about Alaska. I went to bed after my
midnight metereological observation.

Had Jack Bussey in the basket this morning. I think
this will be the last because I want to have start
packing my stuff for home. The Star which is
leaving Dunedin tomorrow will be here about the 27th
and I want to have everything ready. I shall try
to avoid any last minute rush as I had in Boston
Most of the day was spent doing gas analyses.

Tony presented me not only with a special Bear
cachet but also with cancelled stamped envelopeds
bearing the cancellation stpaamps of the various places
visited on her trip down here. They make a very valuable
collection. When I get home I shall make a cachet
of linoleum or wood and cachet these envelopes. Then
they will be collectors items. I also shall have
Wallace the yeoman and postmaster aboard the Bear
cancel some stamped envelopes so that I can have
many left over after I send my mail out.

Not much activity in camp today. Pete made
several hops just for fun and also to make a
Bay of Whales sun aerial survey with Shirley doing the
photographing. Jack R. and Fitz layed out some
markers.
I spent some time reading funny parts.
